awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Benjamin Seeger "Topics in nonlinear stochastic partial differential equations." The host institution for the fellowship is College de France Institute of Numerical Sciences, and the sponsoring scientist is Pierre-Louis Lions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this research project was the investigation of complex dynamical phenomena with statistical uncertainty, arising in models for systems in the physical and social sciences. In particular, the project involved the study of certain nonlinear stochastic partial differential equations (SPDE). The research was carried out at the Collège de France in Paris with Professor Pierre-Louis Lions as the research mentor.

The first main objective involved the theory of homogenization, which is an active area of research in view of both the theoretical and practical applications. Its aim is to replace a random, complicated heterogenous model with a simpler, deterministic, homogenous one that shares the same macroscopic properties. The investigation of long time, large scale behavior of models for front propagation and stochastic control theory in rough media leads naturally to the homogenization of certain nonlinear partial differential equations. Many stochastic processes modeling real-world statistical uncertainty are derived from scaling limits, which motivates the study the homogenization of nonlinear SPDE with multiplicative stochastic noise. As part of the research conducted under this project, the PI published three papers investigating various settings under which homogenization can be established, as well as exploring the consequences of the results in terms of the qualitative behavior of the homogenized models.

The investigator also studied certain SPDEs for which a mathematical understanding was previously unknown. One of the papers published during this time involved equations with data satisfying very limited regularity properties, in which abstract interpolation techniques were used to characterize regimes of solvability for the resulting equations, with concrete examples and approximation techniques. Another direction, which resulted in another published paper, involved equations posed on bounded domains, rather than all of space, which is particularly important for modeling considerations. The PI also began working on projects dealing with rough paths, which can be used for modeling the processing of irregular and stochastic signals. This resulted in a published paper as well as several ongoing projects.

Finally, the PI completed and initiated several research projects involving mean field games (MFG). These are general models for competitive behavior among large populations, and there study has been applied to models in macroeconomics, cryptocurrency, telecommunications, and traffic control. The PI's work on MFG resulted in one published and three submitted papers, involving topics such as dimension reduction, which has particular use for modeling and numerical approximations; the well-posedness of systems with diverse types of stochastic noise influences; and a systematic study of mean field games with a finite state space and the resulting ill-posed equations that arise.

Over the course of the project, the PI developed professional relationships with several researchers, which have led to several ongoing projects in topics related to those described above. The PI participated in intense dissemination activities at seminars and conferences, while also discussing work with more junior researchers and providing guidance and mentorship. Followed the postdoctoral fellowship at Collège de France, the PI has held a postdoctoral appointment at the University of Texas at Austin, where he has continued his research in these areas while branching out into other related topics. The PI was subsequently awarded an individual research grant from the NSF. He continues to develop his mentorship skills, encouraging underrepresented groups in the sciences, as evidenced by his teaching record and his involvement with the Association for Women in Mathematics.
